question: (a) State two ways in which the mesophyll layer of the leaf is adapted for photosynthesis (b) In the test for starch in a leaf, why is the leaf boiled in warm alcohol?
answer: (a) (i) It posses chloroplast which is the main centre for photosynthesis (ii) it has air spaces in which carbon (iv) oxide accumulates and is used to carry out photosynthesis (b) in order to remove the chlorophyll

question: List three uses of fibres to plants.
answer: (i) Mechanical support (ii) rigidity to plant (iii) flexibility to plant

question: Explain briefly how a large quantity of dead organic materials dumped into a river can be harmful to aquatic life.
answer: Dumping of refuse without a commensurate introduction of Oxygen to aid decomposition by aerobes calls for pollution of the river. This is because the carbon (|V) OXIde is increased coupled with the fact that the rate of decomposition is low. Aquatic organisms die as a result of this. The method of addition of  measured quantity of oxygen when a given quantity of refuse is dumped at a given time in a river or sea termed B, O D (Bichemical Oxygen Demand)

question: Name the physical processes responsible for the following (a) entry of carbon dioxide into the leaf through the stomata (b) entry of soil water into the root hair (c) shrinkage of plant tissue in hypertonic sugar solution
answer: (a) Diffusion (b) Osmosis (c) Plasmolysis (d) Hepatic portal vein

question: Name the blood vessel that carries digested food to the liver.
answer: They are specific in their actions, Example starch- splitting enzymes can only act on starch (ii) They work best at a particular temperature. Example - the human enzymes work best between 35°G and 40°C. They are denatured at about 60°C. (iii) They are protein in nature

question: List three harmful effects of noise pollution.
answer: (i) Noise causes hearing defects (ii) Noise can make us lose concentration (iii) Noise pollution quickens heartbeat rate and blood circulation

question: Name one example of symbiotic relationship in animals
answer: (i) Escherichia coli are bacteria found in the intestinal tract of ruminants (and other vertebrates) where they synthesize Vitamin K from cellulose (ii) - Others are protozoa living in the gut of termites - Sea anemone and the hermit crab
